requirement_level.conditionally_required: if available and not equal to `assistant`.

fields.brief: The tool calls generated by the model, such as function calls.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if available

fields.brief: The id of the tool call.
The type of the tool.
The function that the model called.
The name of the function.
The arguments of the function as provided in the LLM response.
fields.note:
Models usually return arguments as a JSON string. In this case, it's RECOMMENDED to provide arguments as is without attempting to deserialize them.
Semantic conventions for individual systems MAY specify a different type for arguments field.

groups.brief: This document defines the shared attributes used to report an error.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.
attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

- Use a domain-specific attribute
- Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

groups.brief: Memory used by the Go runtime.
groups.note: Computed from `(/memory/classes/total:bytes - /memory/classes/heap/released:bytes)`.

attributes.name: go.memory.type

members.brief: Memory allocated from the heap that is reserved for stack space, whether or not it is currently in-use.
Memory used by the Go runtime, excluding other categories of memory usage described in this enumeration.

attributes.brief: The type of memory.

groups.brief: Go runtime memory limit configured by the user, if a limit exists.
groups.note: Computed from `/gc/gomemlimit:bytes`. This metric is excluded if the limit obtained from the Go runtime is math.MaxInt64.

groups.brief: Memory allocated to the heap by the application.
groups.note: Computed from `/gc/heap/allocs:bytes`.

groups.brief: Count of allocations to the heap by the application.
groups.note: Computed from `/gc/heap/allocs:objects`.

groups.brief: Heap size target for the end of the GC cycle.
groups.note: Computed from `/gc/heap/goal:bytes`.

groups.brief: Count of live goroutines.
groups.note: Computed from `/sched/goroutines:goroutines`.

groups.brief: The number of OS threads that can execute user-level Go code simultaneously.
groups.note: Computed from `/sched/gomaxprocs:threads`.

groups.brief: The time goroutines have spent in the scheduler in a runnable state before actually running.
groups.note: Computed from `/sched/latencies:seconds`. Bucket boundaries are provided by the runtime, and are subject to change.

groups.brief: Heap size target percentage configured by the user, otherwise 100.
groups.note: The value range is [0.0,100.0]. Computed from `/gc/gogc:percent`.

groups.brief: This group describes attributes specific to pipelines within a Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) system. A [pipeline](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pipeline_(computing)) in this case is a series of steps that are performed in order to deliver a new version of software. This aligns with the [Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/pipeline) definition of a pipeline where a **pipeline** is the system for developing and producing something. In the context of CI/CD, a pipeline produces or delivers software.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.name
attributes.brief: The human readable name of the pipeline within a CI/CD system.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.run.id
attributes.brief: The unique identifier of a pipeline run within a CI/CD system.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.run.url.full
attributes.brief: The [URL](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/URL) of the pipeline run, providing the complete address in order to locate and identify the pipeline run.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.run.state

members.brief: The run pending state spans from the event triggering the pipeline run until the execution of the run starts (eg. time spent in a queue, provisioning agents, creating run resources).
The executing state spans the execution of any run tasks (eg. build, test).
The finalizing state spans from when the run has finished executing (eg. cleanup of run resources).

attributes.brief: The pipeline run goes through these states during its lifecycle.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.task.name
attributes.brief: The human readable name of a task within a pipeline. Task here most closely aligns with a [computing process](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Pipeline_(computing)) in a pipeline. Other terms for tasks include commands, steps, and procedures.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.task.run.id
attributes.brief: The unique identifier of a task run within a pipeline.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.task.run.url.full
attributes.brief: The [URL](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/URL) of the pipeline task run, providing the complete address in order to locate and identify the pipeline task run.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.task.type
attributes.brief: The type of the task within a pipeline.

attributes.name: cicd.pipeline.result

members.brief: The pipeline run did not finish successfully, eg. due to a compile error or a failing test. Such failures are usually detected by non-zero exit codes of the tools executed in the pipeline run.
The pipeline run failed due to an error in the CICD system, eg. due to the worker being killed.
A timeout caused the pipeline run to be interrupted.
The pipeline run was cancelled, eg. by a user manually cancelling the pipeline run.
The pipeline run was skipped, eg. due to a precondition not being met.

attributes.brief: The result of a pipeline run.

attributes.name: cicd.worker.state

members.brief: The worker is not performing work for the CICD system. It is available to the CICD system to perform work on (online / idle).
members.note: Pipelines might have conditions on which workers they are able to run so not every worker might be available to every pipeline.

members.brief: The worker is performing work for the CICD system.
The worker is not available to the CICD system (disconnected / down).

attributes.brief: The state of a CICD worker / agent.

attributes.name: cicd.system.component
attributes.brief: The name of a component of the CICD system.

groups.brief: The number of changes (pull requests/merge requests/changelists) in a repository, categorized by their state (e.g. open or merged)

attributes.name: vcs.repository.name
attributes.brief: The human readable name of the repository. It SHOULD NOT include any additional identifier like Group/SubGroup in GitLab or organization in GitHub.
attributes.note:
Due to it only being the name, it can clash with forks of the same
repository if collecting telemetry across multiple orgs or groups in
the same backends.

attributes.name: vcs.change.state

members.brief: Open means the change is currently active and under review. It hasn't been merged into the target branch yet, and it's still possible to make changes or add comments.
WIP (work-in-progress, draft) means the change is still in progress and not yet ready for a full review. It might still undergo significant changes.

Closed means the merge request has been closed without merging. This can happen for various reasons, such as the changes being deemed unnecessary, the issue being resolved in another way, or the author deciding to withdraw the request.
Merged indicates that the change has been successfully integrated into the target codebase.

attributes.brief: The state of the change (pull request/merge request/changelist).

attributes.name: vcs.repository.url.full
attributes.brief: The [canonical URL](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/10347851?hl=en#:~:text=A%20canonical%20URL%20is%20the,Google%20chooses%20one%20as%20canonical.) of the repository providing the complete HTTP(S) address in order to locate and identify the repository through a browser.
attributes.note:
In Git Version Control Systems, the canonical URL SHOULD NOT include
the `.git` extension.

groups.brief: The time duration a change (pull request/merge request/changelist) has been in a given state.

Closed means the merge request has been closed without merging. This can happen for various reasons, such as the changes being deemed unnecessary, the issue being resolved in another way, or the author deciding to withdraw the request.
Merged indicates that the change has been successfully integrated into the target codebase.

attributes.note:
`base` refers to the starting point of a change. For example, `main`

attributes.brief: The [canonical URL](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/10347851?hl=en#:~:text=A%20canonical%20URL%20is%20the,Google%20chooses%20one%20as%20canonical.) of the repository providing the complete HTTP(S) address in order to locate and identify the repository through a browser.

attributes.name: vcs.ref.head.name
attributes.brief: The name of the [reference](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitglossary#def_ref) such as **branch** or **tag** in the repository.
attributes.note:
`head` refers to where you are right now; the current reference at a
given time.

attributes.name: vcs.ref.head.revision
attributes.brief: The revision, literally [revised version](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/revision), The revision most often refers to a commit object in Git, or a revision number in SVN.
attributes.note:
`head` refers to where you are right now; the current reference at a
given time.The revision can be a full [hash value (see
glossary)](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.186-5.pdf),
of the recorded change to a ref within a repository pointing to a
commit [commit](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-commit) object. It does
not necessarily have to be a hash; it can simply define a [revision
number](https://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.7/svn.tour.revs.specifiers.html)
which is an integer that is monotonically increasing. In cases where
it is identical to the `ref.head.name`, it SHOULD still be included.
It is up to the implementer to decide which value to set as the
revision based on the VCS system and situational context.

attributes.name: vcs.ref.base.revision
attributes.brief: The revision, literally [revised version](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/revision), The revision most often refers to a commit object in Git, or a revision number in SVN.
attributes.note:
`base` refers to the starting point of a change. For example, `main`
would be the base reference of type branch if you've created a new
reference of type branch from it and created new commits. The
revision can be a full [hash value (see
glossary)](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.186-5.pdf),
of the recorded change to a ref within a repository pointing to a
commit [commit](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-commit) object. It does
not necessarily have to be a hash; it can simply define a [revision
number](https://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.7/svn.tour.revs.specifiers.html)
which is an integer that is monotonically increasing. In cases where
it is identical to the `ref.base.name`, it SHOULD still be included.
It is up to the implementer to decide which value to set as the
revision based on the VCS system and situational context.

groups.brief: The amount of time since its creation it took a change (pull request/merge request/changelist) to get merged into the target(base) ref.

attributes.name: vcs.repository.name
attributes.brief: The human readable name of the repository. It SHOULD NOT include any additional identifier like Group/SubGroup in GitLab or organization in GitHub.
attributes.note:
Due to it only being the name, it can clash with forks of the same
repository if collecting telemetry across multiple orgs or groups in
the same backends.

attributes.name: vcs.ref.base.name
attributes.brief: The name of the [reference](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitglossary#def_ref) such as **branch** or **tag** in the repository.
attributes.note:
`base` refers to the starting point of a change. For example, `main`
would be the base reference of type branch if you've created a new
reference of type branch from it and created new commits.

attributes.name: vcs.repository.url.full
attributes.brief: The [canonical URL](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/10347851?hl=en#:~:text=A%20canonical%20URL%20is%20the,Google%20chooses%20one%20as%20canonical.) of the repository providing the complete HTTP(S) address in order to locate and identify the repository through a browser.
attributes.note:

attributes.name: vcs.ref.head.name
attributes.brief: The name of the [reference](https://git-scm.com/docs/gitglossary#def_ref) such as **branch** or **tag** in the repository.
attributes.note:

attributes.name: vcs.ref.head.revision
attributes.brief: The revision, literally [revised version](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/revision), The revision most often refers to a commit object in Git, or a revision number in SVN.
attributes.note:
`head` refers to where you are right now; the current reference at a
given time.The revision can be a full [hash value (see
glossary)](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.186-5.pdf),
of the recorded change to a ref within a repository pointing to a
commit [commit](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-commit) object. It does
not necessarily have to be a hash; it can simply define a [revision
number](https://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.7/svn.tour.revs.specifiers.html)
which is an integer that is monotonically increasing. In cases where
it is identical to the `ref.head.name`, it SHOULD still be included.
It is up to the implementer to decide which value to set as the
revision based on the VCS system and situational context.

attributes.name: vcs.ref.base.revision

attributes.note:

would be the base reference of type branch if you've created a new

groups.brief: This document defines attributes for software deployments.

attributes.name: deployment.name
attributes.brief: The name of the deployment.

attributes.name: deployment.id
attributes.brief: The id of the deployment.

attributes.name: deployment.status
attributes.brief: The status of the deployment.

attributes.name: deployment.environment.name
attributes.brief: Name of the [deployment environment](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_environment) (aka deployment tier).
attributes.note:
`deployment.environment.name` does not affect the uniqueness constraints defined through
the `service.namespace`, `service.name` and `service.instance.id` resource attributes.
This implies that resources carrying the following attribute combinations MUST be
considered to be identifying the same service:

- `service.name=frontend`, `deployment.environment.name=production`
- `service.name=frontend`, `deployment.environment.name=staging`.

groups.brief: This event represents an occurrence of a lifecycle transition on Android or iOS platform.
groups.note:
The event body fields MUST be used to describe the state of the application at the time of the event.
This event is meant to be used in conjunction with `os.name` [resource semantic convention](/docs/resource/os.md) to identify the mobile operating system (e.g. Android, iOS).
The `android.app.state` and `ios.app.state` fields are mutually exclusive and MUST NOT be used together, each field MUST be used with its corresponding `os.name` value.

attributes.name: ios.app.state

members.brief: The app has become `active`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidBecomeActive`.
The app is now `inactive`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillResignActive`.
The app is now in the background. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidEnterBackground`.
The app is now in the foreground. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillEnterForeground`.
The app is about to terminate. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillTerminate`.

attributes.brief: This attribute represents the state of the application.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if `os.name` is `ios`

attributes.note: The iOS lifecycle states are defined in the [UIApplicationDelegate documentation](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiapplicationdelegate), and from which the `OS terminology` column values are derived.

attributes.name: android.app.state

members.brief: Any time before Activity.onResume() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.startService() has been called in the app for the first time.
Any time after Activity.onPause() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.stopService() has been called when the app was in the foreground state.
Any time after Activity.onResume() or, if the app has no Activity, Context.startService() has been called when the app was in either the created or background states.

attributes.brief: This attribute represents the state of the application.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if `os.name` is `android`

attributes.note: The Android lifecycle states are defined in [Activity lifecycle callbacks](https://developer.android.com/guide/components/activities/activity-lifecycle#lc), and from which the `OS identifiers` are derived.

groups.name: device.app.lifecycle

groups.brief: Span attributes used by AWS Lambda (in addition to general `faas` attributes).

attributes.name: aws.lambda.invoked_arn
attributes.brief: The full invoked ARN as provided on the `Context` passed to the function (`Lambda-Runtime-Invoked-Function-Arn` header on the `/runtime/invocation/next` applicable).
attributes.note: This may be different from `cloud.resource_id` if an alias is involved.

groups.brief: A service instance.

attributes.name: service.name
attributes.brief: Logical name of the service.
attributes.note: MUST be the same for all instances of horizontally scaled services. If the value was not specified, SDKs MUST fallback to `unknown_service:` concatenated with [`process.executable.name`](process.md), e.g. `unknown_service:bash`. If `process.executable.name` is not available, the value MUST be set to `unknown_service`.

attributes.name: service.version
attributes.brief: The version string of the service API or implementation. The format is not defined by these conventions.

attributes.name: service.namespace
attributes.brief: A namespace for `service.name`.
attributes.note: A string value having a meaning that helps to distinguish a group of services, for example the team name that owns a group of services. `service.name` is expected to be unique within the same namespace. If `service.namespace` is not specified in the Resource then `service.name` is expected to be unique for all services that have no explicit namespace defined (so the empty/unspecified namespace is simply one more valid namespace). Zero-length namespace string is assumed equal to unspecified namespace.

attributes.name: service.instance.id
attributes.brief: The string ID of the service instance.
attributes.note:
MUST be unique for each instance of the same `service.namespace,service.name` pair (in other words
`service.namespace,service.name,service.instance.id` triplet MUST be globally unique). The ID helps to
distinguish instances of the same service that exist at the same time (e.g. instances of a horizontally scaled
service).

Implementations, such as SDKs, are recommended to generate a random Version 1 or Version 4 [RFC
4122](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt) UUID, but are free to use an inherent unique ID as the source of
this value if stability is desirable. In that case, the ID SHOULD be used as source of a UUID Version 5 and
SHOULD use the following UUID as the namespace: `4d63009a-8d0f-11ee-aad7-4c796ed8e320`.

UUIDs are typically recommended, as only an opaque value for the purposes of identifying a service instance is
needed. Similar to what can be seen in the man page for the
[`/etc/machine-id`](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/latest/machine-id.html) file, the underlying
data, such as pod name and namespace should be treated as confidential, being the user's choice to expose it
or not via another resource attribute.

For applications running behind an application server (like unicorn), we do not recommend using one identifier
for all processes participating in the application. Instead, it's recommended each division (e.g. a worker
thread in unicorn) to have its own instance.id.

It's not recommended for a Collector to set `service.instance.id` if it can't unambiguously determine the
service instance that is generating that telemetry. For instance, creating an UUID based on `pod.name` will
likely be wrong, as the Collector might not know from which container within that pod the telemetry originated.
However, Collectors can set the `service.instance.id` if they can unambiguously determine the service instance
for that telemetry. This is typically the case for scraping receivers, as they know the target address and
port.

groups.brief: Measures the time taken to perform a DNS lookup.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes the error the DNS lookup failed with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if an error has occurred.

attributes.note: Instrumentations SHOULD use error code such as one of errors reported by `getaddrinfo`([Linux or other POSIX systems](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/getaddrinfo.3.html) / [Windows](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/win32/api/ws2tcpip/nf-ws2tcpip-getaddrinfo)) or one reported by the runtime or client library. If error code is not available, the full name of exception type SHOULD be used.

attributes.name: dns.question.name
attributes.brief: The name being queried.
attributes.note: If the name field contains non-printable characters (below 32 or above 126), those characters should be represented as escaped base 10 integers (\DDD). Back slashes and quotes should be escaped. Tabs, carriage returns, and line feeds should be converted to \t, \r, and \n respectively.

groups.brief: Common messaging metrics attributes.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

- Use a domain-specific attribute
- Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.partition.id
attributes.brief: The identifier of the partition messages are sent to or received from, unique within the `messaging.destination.name`.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if `messaging.destination.name` is known to have low cardinality. Otherwise, `messaging.destination.template` MAY be populated.

attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.template
attributes.brief: Low cardinality representation of the messaging destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if available.

attributes.note: Destination names could be constructed from templates. An example would be a destination name involving a user name or product id. Although the destination name in this case is of high cardinality, the underlying template is of low cardinality and can be effectively used for grouping and aggregation.

attributes.name: messaging.system
attributes.brief: The messaging system as identified by the client instrumentation.
attributes.note: The actual messaging system may differ from the one known by the client. For example, when using Kafka client libraries to communicate with Azure Event Hubs, the `messaging.system` is set to `kafka` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.

attributes.brief: The identifier of the partition messages are sent to or received from, unique within the `messaging.destination.name`.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if and only if `messaging.destination.name` is known to have low cardinality. Otherwise, `messaging.destination.template` MAY be populated.

attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.template
attributes.brief: Low cardinality representation of the messaging destination name

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if available.

attributes.note: Destination names could be constructed from templates. An example would be a destination name involving a user name or product id. Although the destination name in this case is of high cardinality, the underlying template is of low cardinality and can be effectively used for grouping and aggregation.

attributes.name: messaging.system
attributes.brief: The messaging system as identified by the client instrumentation.
attributes.note: The actual messaging system may differ from the one known by the client. For example, when using Kafka client libraries to communicate with Azure Event Hubs, the `messaging.system` is set to `kafka` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.

attributes.name: messaging.consumer.group.name
attributes.brief: The name of the consumer group with which a consumer is associated.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if applicable.

attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.consumer.group.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.subscription.name
attributes.brief: The name of the destination subscription from which a message is consumed.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: if applicable.

attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.destination.subscription.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.type

members.brief: A message is created. "Create" spans always refer to a single message and are used to provide a unique creation context for messages in batch sending scenarios.

One or more messages are provided for sending to an intermediary. If a single message is sent, the context of the "Send" span can be used as the creation context and no "Create" span needs to be created.
One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

attributes.brief: A string identifying the type of the messaging operation.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If applicable.

attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

groups.brief: Duration of processing operation.
groups.note: This metric MUST be reported for operations with `messaging.operation.type` that matches `process`.

attributes.name: server.port
attributes.brief: Server port number.
attributes.note: When observed from the client side, and when communicating through an intermediary, `server.port` SHOULD represent the server port behind any intermediaries, for example proxies, if it's available.

attributes.name: server.address
attributes.brief: Server domain name if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

attributes.note: Server domain name of the broker if available without reverse DNS lookup; otherwise, IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: error.type

members.brief: A fallback error value to be used when the instrumentation doesn't define a custom value.

attributes.brief: Describes a class of error the operation ended with.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If and only if the messaging operation has failed.

attributes.note:
The `error.type` SHOULD be predictable, and SHOULD have low cardinality.

When `error.type` is set to a type (e.g., an exception type), its
canonical class name identifying the type within the artifact SHOULD be used.

Instrumentations SHOULD document the list of errors they report.

The cardinality of `error.type` within one instrumentation library SHOULD be low.
Telemetry consumers that aggregate data from multiple instrumentation libraries and applications
should be prepared for `error.type` to have high cardinality at query time when no
additional filters are applied.

If the operation has completed successfully, instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `error.type`.

If a specific domain defines its own set of error identifiers (such as HTTP or gRPC status codes),
it's RECOMMENDED to:

- Use a domain-specific attribute
- Set `error.type` to capture all errors, regardless of whether they are defined within the domain-specific set or not.

groups.brief: An operating system process.

attributes.name: process.pid
attributes.brief: Process identifier (PID).

attributes.name: process.parent_pid
attributes.brief: Parent Process identifier (PPID).

attributes.name: process.vpid
attributes.brief: Virtual process identifier.
attributes.note: The process ID within a PID namespace. This is not necessarily unique across all processes on the host but it is unique within the process namespace that the process exists within.

attributes.name: process.session_leader.pid
attributes.brief: The PID of the process's session leader. This is also the session ID (SID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.group_leader.pid
attributes.brief: The PID of the process's group leader. This is also the process group ID (PGID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.executable.build_id.gnu
attributes.brief: The GNU build ID as found in the `.note.gnu.build-id` ELF section (hex string).

attributes.name: process.executable.build_id.go
attributes.brief: The Go build ID as retrieved by `go tool buildid <go executable>`.

attributes.name: process.executable.build_id.htlhash
attributes.brief: Profiling specific build ID for executables. See the OTel specification for Profiles for more information.

attributes.name: process.executable.name
attributes.brief: The name of the process executable. On Linux based systems, this SHOULD be set to the base name of the target of `/proc/[pid]/exe`. On Windows, this SHOULD be set to the base name of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

attributes.name: process.executable.path
attributes.brief: The full path to the process executable. On Linux based systems, can be set to the target of `proc/[pid]/exe`. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetProcessImageFileNameW`.

attributes.name: process.command
attributes.brief: The command used to launch the process (i.e. the command name). On Linux based systems, can be set to the zeroth string in `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. On Windows, can be set to the first parameter extracted from `GetCommandLineW`.

attributes.name: process.command_line
attributes.brief: The full command used to launch the process as a single string representing the full command. On Windows, can be set to the result of `GetCommandLineW`. Do not set this if you have to assemble it just for monitoring; use `process.command_args` instead.

attributes.name: process.command_args
attributes.brief: All the command arguments (including the command/executable itself) as received by the process. On Linux-based systems (and some other Unixoid systems supporting procfs), can be set according to the list of null-delimited strings extracted from `proc/[pid]/cmdline`. For libc-based executables, this would be the full argv vector passed to `main`.

attributes.name: process.args_count
attributes.brief: Length of the process.command_args array
attributes.note: This field can be useful for querying or performing bucket analysis on how many arguments were provided to start a process. More arguments may be an indication of suspicious activity.

attributes.name: process.owner
attributes.brief: The username of the user that owns the process.

attributes.name: process.user.id
attributes.brief: The effective user ID (EUID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.user.name
attributes.brief: The username of the effective user of the process.

attributes.name: process.real_user.id
attributes.brief: The real user ID (RUID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.real_user.name
attributes.brief: The username of the real user of the process.

attributes.name: process.saved_user.id
attributes.brief: The saved user ID (SUID) of the process.

attributes.name: process.saved_user.name
attributes.brief: The username of the saved user.

attributes.name: process.runtime.name
attributes.brief: The name of the runtime of this process.

attributes.name: process.runtime.version
attributes.brief: The version of the runtime of this process, as returned by the runtime without modification.

attributes.name: process.runtime.description
attributes.brief: An additional description about the runtime of the process, for example a specific vendor customization of the runtime environment.
attributes.examples: Eclipse OpenJ9 Eclipse OpenJ9 VM openj9-0.21.0

attributes.name: process.title
attributes.brief: Process title (proctitle)
attributes.note: In many Unix-like systems, process title (proctitle), is the string that represents the name or command line of a running process, displayed by system monitoring tools like ps, top, and htop.

attributes.name: process.creation.time
attributes.brief: The date and time the process was created, in ISO 8601 format.

attributes.name: process.exit.time
attributes.brief: The date and time the process exited, in ISO 8601 format.

attributes.name: process.exit.code
attributes.brief: The exit code of the process.

attributes.name: process.interactive
attributes.brief: Whether the process is connected to an interactive shell.

attributes.name: process.working_directory
attributes.brief: The working directory of the process.

attributes.name: process.context_switch_type
attributes.brief: Specifies whether the context switches for this data point were voluntary or involuntary.

attributes.name: process.paging.fault_type
attributes.brief: The type of page fault for this data point. Type `major` is for major/hard page faults, and `minor` is for minor/soft page faults.

groups.brief: Describes Linux Process attributes

attributes.name: process.linux.cgroup
attributes.brief: The control group associated with the process.
attributes.note: Control groups (cgroups) are a kernel feature used to organize and manage process resources. This attribute provides the path(s) to the cgroup(s) associated with the process, which should match the contents of the [/proc/\[PID\]/cgroup](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/cgroups.7.html) file.

groups.brief: Resource describing the packaged software running the application code. Web engines are typically executed using process.runtime.

attributes.name: webengine.version
attributes.brief: The version of the web engine.

attributes.name: webengine.description
attributes.brief: Additional description of the web engine (e.g. detailed version and edition information).

attributes.name: webengine.name
attributes.brief: The name of the web engine.

groups.name: webengine

groups.brief: Describes file attributes.

attributes.name: file.accessed
attributes.brief: Time when the file was last accessed, in ISO 8601 format.
attributes.note: This attribute might not be supported by some file systems ‚Äî NFS, FAT32, in embedded OS, etc.

attributes.name: file.attributes
attributes.brief: Array of file attributes.
attributes.note: Attributes names depend on the OS or file system. Here‚Äôs a non-exhaustive list of values expected for this attribute: `archive`, `compressed`, `directory`, `encrypted`, `execute`, `hidden`, `immutable`, `journaled`, `read`, `readonly`, `symbolic link`, `system`, `temporary`, `write`.

attributes.name: file.created
attributes.brief: Time when the file was created, in ISO 8601 format.
attributes.note: This attribute might not be supported by some file systems ‚Äî NFS, FAT32, in embedded OS, etc.

attributes.name: file.changed
attributes.brief: Time when the file attributes or metadata was last changed, in ISO 8601 format.
attributes.note: `file.changed` captures the time when any of the file's properties or attributes (including the content) are changed, while `file.modified` captures the timestamp when the file content is modified.

attributes.name: file.directory
attributes.brief: Directory where the file is located. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

attributes.name: file.extension
attributes.brief: File extension, excluding the leading dot.
attributes.note: When the file name has multiple extensions (example.tar.gz), only the last one should be captured ("gz", not "tar.gz").

attributes.name: file.fork_name
attributes.brief: Name of the fork. A fork is additional data associated with a filesystem object.
attributes.note:
On Linux, a resource fork is used to store additional data with a filesystem object. A file always has at least one fork for the data portion, and additional forks may exist.
On NTFS, this is analogous to an Alternate Data Stream (ADS), and the default data stream for a file is just called $DATA. Zone.Identifier is commonly used by Windows to track contents downloaded from the Internet. An ADS is typically of the form: C:\path\to\filename.extension:some_fork_name, and some_fork_name is the value that should populate `fork_name`. `filename.extension` should populate `file.name`, and `extension` should populate `file.extension`. The full path, `file.path`, will include the fork name.

attributes.name: file.group.id
attributes.brief: Primary Group ID (GID) of the file.

attributes.name: file.group.name
attributes.brief: Primary group name of the file.

attributes.name: file.inode
attributes.brief: Inode representing the file in the filesystem.

attributes.name: file.mode
attributes.brief: Mode of the file in octal representation.

attributes.name: file.modified
attributes.brief: Time when the file content was last modified, in ISO 8601 format.

attributes.name: file.name
attributes.brief: Name of the file including the extension, without the directory.

attributes.name: file.owner.id
attributes.brief: The user ID (UID) or security identifier (SID) of the file owner.

attributes.name: file.owner.name
attributes.brief: Username of the file owner.

attributes.name: file.path
attributes.brief: Full path to the file, including the file name. It should include the drive letter, when appropriate.

attributes.name: file.size
attributes.brief: File size in bytes.

attributes.name: file.symbolic_link.target_path
attributes.brief: Path to the target of a symbolic link.
attributes.note: This attribute is only applicable to symbolic links.

attributes.brief: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 2-character country code associated with the mobile carrier network.

attributes.name: network.carrier.mcc
attributes.brief: The mobile carrier country code.

attributes.name: network.carrier.mnc
attributes.brief: The mobile carrier network code.

attributes.name: network.carrier.name
attributes.brief: The name of the mobile carrier.

attributes.name: network.connection.subtype
attributes.brief: This describes more details regarding the connection.type. It may be the type of cell technology connection, but it could be used for describing details about a wifi connection.

attributes.name: network.connection.type
attributes.brief: The internet connection type.

attributes.name: network.local.address
attributes.brief: Local address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.local.port
attributes.brief: Local port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_layer) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_layer) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

attributes.name: network.type
attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_layer) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.io.direction
attributes.brief: The network IO operation direction.

attributes.name: network.interface.name
attributes.brief: The network interface name.

attributes.name: network.connection.state
attributes.brief: The state of network connection
attributes.note: Connection states are defined as part of the [rfc9293](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9293#section-3.3.2)

groups.brief: Resource used by Google Cloud Run.

attributes.name: gcp.cloud_run.job.execution
attributes.brief: The name of the Cloud Run [execution](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/managing/job-executions) being run for the Job, as set by the [`CLOUD_RUN_EXECUTION`](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/container-contract#jobs-env-vars) environment variable.

attributes.name: gcp.cloud_run.job.task_index
attributes.brief: The index for a task within an execution as provided by the [`CLOUD_RUN_TASK_INDEX`](https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/container-contract#jobs-env-vars) environment variable.

attributes.name: ios.state

members.brief: The app has become `active`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidBecomeActive`.
The app is now `inactive`. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillResignActive`.
The app is now in the background. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationDidEnterBackground`.
The app is now in the foreground. This value is associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillEnterForeground`.
The app is about to terminate. Associated with UIKit notification `applicationWillTerminate`.

attributes.brief: Deprecated. use the `ios.app.state` instead.
attributes.note: The iOS lifecycle states are defined in the [UIApplicationDelegate documentation](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uiapplicationdelegate), and from which the `OS terminology` column values are derived.

When CPU is used by the system (host OS)
When tasks of the cgroup are in kernel mode (Linux). When all container processes are in kernel mode (Windows).

groups.brief: This document defines semantic convention attributes in the HTTP namespace.

attributes.name: http.request.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the request payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.request.header
attributes.brief: HTTP request headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all request headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
The `User-Agent` header is already captured in the `user_agent.original` attribute. Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.request.method

members.brief: Any HTTP method that the instrumentation has no prior knowledge of.

attributes.brief: HTTP request method.
attributes.note:
HTTP request method value SHOULD be "known" to the instrumentation.
By default, this convention defines "known" methods as the ones listed in [RFC9110](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#name-methods)
and the PATCH method defined in [RFC5789](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5789.html).

If the HTTP request method is not known to instrumentation, it MUST set the `http.request.method` attribute to `_OTHER`.

If the HTTP instrumentation could end up converting valid HTTP request methods to `_OTHER`, then it MUST provide a way to override
the list of known HTTP methods. If this override is done via environment variable, then the environment variable MUST be named
OTEL_INSTRUMENTATION_HTTP_KNOWN_METHODS and support a comma-separated list of case-sensitive known HTTP methods
(this list MUST be a full override of the default known method, it is not a list of known methods in addition to the defaults).

HTTP method names are case-sensitive and `http.request.method` attribute value MUST match a known HTTP method name exactly.
Instrumentations for specific web frameworks that consider HTTP methods to be case insensitive, SHOULD populate a canonical equivalent.
Tracing instrumentations that do so, MUST also set `http.request.method_original` to the original value.

attributes.name: http.request.method_original
attributes.brief: Original HTTP method sent by the client in the request line.

attributes.name: http.request.resend_count
attributes.brief: The ordinal number of request resending attempt (for any reason, including redirects).
attributes.note: The resend count SHOULD be updated each time an HTTP request gets resent by the client, regardless of what was the cause of the resending (e.g. redirection, authorization failure, 503 Server Unavailable, network issues, or any other).

attributes.name: http.request.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the request in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the request line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and request body if any.

attributes.name: http.response.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the response payload body in bytes. This is the number of bytes transferred excluding headers and is often, but not always, present as the [Content-Length](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9110.html#field.content-length) header. For requests using transport encoding, this should be the compressed size.

attributes.name: http.response.header
attributes.brief: HTTP response headers, `<key>` being the normalized HTTP Header name (lowercase), the value being the header values.
attributes.note:
Instrumentations SHOULD require an explicit configuration of which headers are to be captured. Including all response headers can be a security risk - explicit configuration helps avoid leaking sensitive information.
Users MAY explicitly configure instrumentations to capture them even though it is not recommended.
The attribute value MUST consist of either multiple header values as an array of strings or a single-item array containing a possibly comma-concatenated string, depending on the way the HTTP library provides access to headers.

attributes.name: http.response.size
attributes.brief: The total size of the response in bytes. This should be the total number of bytes sent over the wire, including the status line (HTTP/1.1), framing (HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), headers, and response body and trailers if any.

attributes.name: http.response.status_code
attributes.brief: [HTTP response status code](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6).

attributes.name: http.route
attributes.brief: The matched route, that is, the path template in the format used by the respective server framework.
attributes.note:
MUST NOT be populated when this is not supported by the HTTP server framework as the route attribute should have low-cardinality and the URI path can NOT substitute it.
SHOULD include the [application root](/docs/http/http-spans.md#http-server-definitions) if there is one.

attributes.name: http.connection.state
attributes.brief: State of the HTTP connection in the HTTP connection pool.

groups.brief: A cloud environment (e.g. GCP, Azure, AWS)

attributes.name: cloud.provider
attributes.brief: Name of the cloud provider.

attributes.name: cloud.account.id
attributes.brief: The cloud account ID the resource is assigned to.

attributes.name: cloud.region
attributes.brief: The geographical region the resource is running.
attributes.note: Refer to your provider's docs to see the available regions, for example [Alibaba Cloud regions](https://www.alibabacloud.com/help/doc-detail/40654.htm), [AWS regions](https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/global-infrastructure/regions_az/), [Azure regions](https://azure.microsoft.com/global-infrastructure/geographies/), [Google Cloud regions](https://cloud.google.com/about/locations), or [Tencent Cloud regions](https://www.tencentcloud.com/document/product/213/6091).

attributes.name: cloud.resource_id
attributes.brief: Cloud provider-specific native identifier of the monitored cloud resource (e.g. an [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html) on AWS, a [fully qualified resource ID](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) on Azure, a [full resource name](https://google.aip.dev/122#full-resource-names) on GCP)
attributes.note:
On some cloud providers, it may not be possible to determine the full ID at startup,
so it may be necessary to set `cloud.resource_id` as a span attribute instead.

The exact value to use for `cloud.resource_id` depends on the cloud provider.
The following well-known definitions MUST be used if you set this attribute and they apply:

- **AWS Lambda:** The function [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/aws-arns-and-namespaces.html).
  Take care not to use the "invoked ARN" directly but replace any
  [alias suffix](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-aliases.html)
  with the resolved function version, as the same runtime instance may be invocable with
  multiple different aliases.
- **GCP:** The [URI of the resource](https://cloud.google.com/iam/docs/full-resource-names)
- **Azure:** The [Fully Qualified Resource ID](https://docs.microsoft.com/rest/api/resources/resources/get-by-id) of the invoked function,
  *not* the function app, having the form
  `/subscriptions/<SUBSCRIPTION_GUID>/resourceGroups/<RG>/providers/Microsoft.Web/sites/<FUNCAPP>/functions/<FUNC>`.
  This means that a span attribute MUST be used, as an Azure function app can host multiple functions that would usually share
  a TracerProvider.

attributes.name: cloud.availability_zone
attributes.brief: Cloud regions often have multiple, isolated locations known as zones to increase availability. Availability zone represents the zone where the resource is running.
attributes.note: Availability zones are called "zones" on Alibaba Cloud and Google Cloud.

attributes.name: cloud.platform

members.brief: Red Hat OpenShift on Alibaba Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on Google Cloud
Red Hat OpenShift on IBM Cloud
Kubernetes Engine (OKE) on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)

attributes.brief: The cloud platform in use.
attributes.note: The prefix of the service SHOULD match the one specified in `cloud.provider`.

groups.name: cloud

groups.brief: The device on which the process represented by this resource is running.

attributes.name: device.id
attributes.brief: A unique identifier representing the device
attributes.note: The device identifier MUST only be defined using the values outlined below. This value is not an advertising identifier and MUST NOT be used as such. On iOS (Swift or Objective-C), this value MUST be equal to the [vendor identifier](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uidevice/1620059-identifierforvendor). On Android (Java or Kotlin), this value MUST be equal to the Firebase Installation ID or a globally unique UUID which is persisted across sessions in your application. More information can be found [here](https://developer.android.com/training/articles/user-data-ids) on best practices and exact implementation details. Caution should be taken when storing personal data or anything which can identify a user. GDPR and data protection laws may apply, ensure you do your own due diligence.

attributes.name: device.manufacturer
attributes.brief: The name of the device manufacturer
attributes.note: The Android OS provides this field via [Build](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build#MANUFACTURER). iOS apps SHOULD hardcode the value `Apple`.

attributes.name: device.model.identifier
attributes.brief: The model identifier for the device
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a machine-readable version of the model identifier rather than the market or consumer-friendly name of the device.

attributes.name: device.model.name
attributes.brief: The marketing name for the device model
attributes.note: It's recommended this value represents a human-readable version of the device model rather than a machine-readable alternative.

groups.name: device

groups.brief:
The `aws` conventions apply to operations using the AWS SDK. They map request or response parameters in AWS SDK API calls to attributes on a Span. The conventions have been collected over time based on feedback from AWS users of tracing and will continue to evolve as new interesting conventions are found.
Some descriptions are also provided for populating general OpenTelemetry semantic conventions based on these APIs.

attributes.name: aws.request_id
attributes.brief: The AWS request ID as returned in the response headers `x-amzn-requestid`, `x-amzn-request-id` or `x-amz-request-id`.

attributes.name: rpc.system
attributes.brief: The value `aws-api`.

attributes.name: rpc.service
attributes.brief: The name of the service to which a request is made, as returned by the AWS SDK.
attributes.note: This is the logical name of the service from the RPC interface perspective, which can be different from the name of any implementing class. The `code.namespace` attribute may be used to store the latter (despite the attribute name, it may include a class name; e.g., class with method actually executing the call on the server side, RPC client stub class on the client side).

attributes.name: rpc.method
attributes.brief: The name of the operation corresponding to the request, as returned by the AWS SDK
attributes.note: This is the logical name of the method from the RPC interface perspective, which can be different from the name of any implementing method/function. The `code.function.name` attribute may be used to store the latter (e.g., method actually executing the call on the server side, RPC client stub method on the client side).

attributes.name: aws.extended_request_id
attributes.brief: The AWS extended request ID as returned in the response header `x-amz-id-2`.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: If available.

groups.brief: Attributes that exist for S3 request types.

attributes.name: aws.request_id
attributes.brief: The AWS request ID as returned in the response headers `x-amzn-requestid`, `x-amzn-request-id` or `x-amz-request-id`.

attributes.name: aws.s3.bucket
attributes.brief: The S3 bucket name the request refers to. Corresponds to the `--bucket` parameter of the [S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/index.html) operations.
attributes.note:
The `bucket` attribute is applicable to all S3 operations that reference a bucket, i.e. that require the bucket name as a mandatory parameter.
This applies to almost all S3 operations except `list-buckets`.

attributes.name: aws.s3.key
attributes.brief: The S3 object key the request refers to. Corresponds to the `--key` parameter of the [S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/index.html) operations.
attributes.note:
The `key` attribute is applicable to all object-related S3 operations, i.e. that require the object key as a mandatory parameter.
This applies in particular to the following operations:

- [copy-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/copy-object.html)
- [delete-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/delete-object.html)
- [get-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/get-object.html)
- [head-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/head-object.html)
- [put-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/put-object.html)
- [restore-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/restore-object.html)
- [select-object-content](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/select-object-content.html)
- [abort-multipart-upload](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/abort-multipart-upload.html)
- [complete-multipart-upload](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/complete-multipart-upload.html)
- [create-multipart-upload](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/create-multipart-upload.html)
- [list-parts](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/list-parts.html)
- [upload-part](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part.html)
- [upload-part-copy](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part-copy.html)

attributes.name: aws.s3.copy_source
attributes.brief: The source object (in the form `bucket`/`key`) for the copy operation.
attributes.note:
The `copy_source` attribute applies to S3 copy operations and corresponds to the `--copy-source` parameter
of the [copy-object operation within the S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/copy-object.html).
This applies in particular to the following operations:

- [copy-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/copy-object.html)
- [upload-part-copy](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part-copy.html)

attributes.name: aws.s3.upload_id
attributes.brief: Upload ID that identifies the multipart upload.
attributes.note:
The `upload_id` attribute applies to S3 multipart-upload operations and corresponds to the `--upload-id` parameter
of the [S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/index.html) multipart operations.
This applies in particular to the following operations:

- [abort-multipart-upload](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/abort-multipart-upload.html)
- [complete-multipart-upload](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/complete-multipart-upload.html)
- [list-parts](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/list-parts.html)
- [upload-part](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part.html)
- [upload-part-copy](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part-copy.html)

attributes.name: aws.s3.delete
attributes.brief: The delete request container that specifies the objects to be deleted.
attributes.note:
The `delete` attribute is only applicable to the [delete-object](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/delete-object.html) operation.
The `delete` attribute corresponds to the `--delete` parameter of the
[delete-objects operation within the S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/delete-objects.html).

attributes.name: aws.s3.part_number
attributes.brief: The part number of the part being uploaded in a multipart-upload operation. This is a positive integer between 1 and 10,000.
attributes.note:
The `part_number` attribute is only applicable to the [upload-part](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part.html)
and [upload-part-copy](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part-copy.html) operations.
The `part_number` attribute corresponds to the `--part-number` parameter of the
[upload-part operation within the S3 API](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/s3api/upload-part.html).

attributes.brief: The value `aws-api`.

groups.brief: Attributes describing telemetry around messaging systems and messaging activities.

attributes.name: messaging.batch.message_count
attributes.brief: The number of messages sent, received, or processed in the scope of the batching operation.
attributes.note: Instrumentations SHOULD NOT set `messaging.batch.message_count` on spans that operate with a single message. When a messaging client library supports both batch and single-message API for the same operation, instrumentations SHOULD use `messaging.batch.message_count` for batching APIs and SHOULD NOT use it for single-message APIs.

attributes.name: messaging.client.id
attributes.brief: A unique identifier for the client that consumes or produces a message.

attributes.name: messaging.consumer.group.name
attributes.brief: The name of the consumer group with which a consumer is associated.
attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.consumer.group.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.name
attributes.brief: The message destination name
attributes.note:
Destination name SHOULD uniquely identify a specific queue, topic or other entity within the broker. If
the broker doesn't have such notion, the destination name SHOULD uniquely identify the broker.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.subscription.name
attributes.brief: The name of the destination subscription from which a message is consumed.
attributes.note: Semantic conventions for individual messaging systems SHOULD document whether `messaging.destination.subscription.name` is applicable and what it means in the context of that system.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.template
attributes.brief: Low cardinality representation of the messaging destination name
attributes.note: Destination names could be constructed from templates. An example would be a destination name involving a user name or product id. Although the destination name in this case is of high cardinality, the underlying template is of low cardinality and can be effectively used for grouping and aggregation.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.anonymous
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the message destination is anonymous (could be unnamed or have auto-generated name).

attributes.name: messaging.destination.temporary
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the message destination is temporary and might not exist anymore after messages are processed.

attributes.name: messaging.destination.partition.id
attributes.brief: The identifier of the partition messages are sent to or received from, unique within the `messaging.destination.name`.

attributes.name: messaging.message.conversation_id
attributes.brief: The conversation ID identifying the conversation to which the message belongs, represented as a string. Sometimes called "Correlation ID".

attributes.name: messaging.message.envelope.size
attributes.brief: The size of the message body and metadata in bytes.
attributes.note:
This can refer to both the compressed or uncompressed size. If both sizes are known, the uncompressed
size should be used.

attributes.name: messaging.message.id
attributes.brief: A value used by the messaging system as an identifier for the message, represented as a string.

attributes.name: messaging.message.body.size
attributes.brief: The size of the message body in bytes.
attributes.note:
This can refer to both the compressed or uncompressed body size. If both sizes are known, the uncompressed
body size should be used.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.type

members.brief: A message is created. "Create" spans always refer to a single message and are used to provide a unique creation context for messages in batch sending scenarios.

One or more messages are provided for sending to an intermediary. If a single message is sent, the context of the "Send" span can be used as the creation context and no "Create" span needs to be created.
One or more messages are requested by a consumer. This operation refers to pull-based scenarios, where consumers explicitly call methods of messaging SDKs to receive messages.
One or more messages are processed by a consumer.
One or more messages are settled.

attributes.brief: A string identifying the type of the messaging operation.
attributes.note: If a custom value is used, it MUST be of low cardinality.

attributes.name: messaging.operation.name
attributes.brief: The system-specific name of the messaging operation.

attributes.name: messaging.system
attributes.brief: The messaging system as identified by the client instrumentation.
attributes.note: The actual messaging system may differ from the one known by the client. For example, when using Kafka client libraries to communicate with Azure Event Hubs, the `messaging.system` is set to `kafka` based on the instrumentation's best knowledge.

groups.brief: This group describes attributes specific to Apache Kafka.

attributes.name: messaging.kafka.message.key
attributes.brief: Message keys in Kafka are used for grouping alike messages to ensure they're processed on the same partition. They differ from `messaging.message.id` in that they're not unique. If the key is `null`, the attribute MUST NOT be set.
attributes.note: If the key type is not string, it's string representation has to be supplied for the attribute. If the key has no unambiguous, canonical string form, don't include its value.

attributes.name: messaging.kafka.offset
attributes.brief: The offset of a record in the corresponding Kafka partition.

attributes.name: messaging.kafka.message.tombstone
attributes.brief: A boolean that is true if the message is a tombstone.

groups.brief: This group describes attributes specific to RabbitMQ.

attributes.name: messaging.rabbitmq.destination.routing_key
attributes.brief: RabbitMQ message routing key.

attributes.name: messaging.rabbitmq.message.delivery_tag
attributes.brief: RabbitMQ message delivery tag

groups.brief: This group describes attributes specific to RocketMQ.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.consumption_model
attributes.brief: Model of message consumption. This only applies to consumer spans.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.delay_time_level
attributes.brief: The delay time level for delay message, which determines the message delay time.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.delivery_timestamp
attributes.brief: The timestamp in milliseconds that the delay message is expected to be delivered to consumer.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.group
attributes.brief: It is essential for FIFO message. Messages that belong to the same message group are always processed one by one within the same consumer group.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.keys
attributes.brief: Key(s) of message, another way to mark message besides message id.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.tag
attributes.brief: The secondary classifier of message besides topic.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.message.type
attributes.brief: Type of message.

attributes.name: messaging.rocketmq.namespace
attributes.brief: Namespace of RocketMQ resources, resources in different namespaces are individual.

groups.brief: This group describes attributes specific to GCP Pub/Sub.

attributes.name: messaging.gcp_pubsub.message.ordering_key

groups.brief: The system component which is monitored.

attributes.name: cloudfoundry.system.id
attributes.brief: A guid or another name describing the event source.
attributes.note:
CloudFoundry defines the `source_id` in the [Loggregator v2 envelope](https://github.com/cloudfoundry/loggregator-api#v2-envelope).
It is used for logs and metrics emitted by CloudFoundry. It is
supposed to contain the component name, e.g. "gorouter", for
CloudFoundry components.

When system components are instrumented, values from the
[Bosh spec](https://bosh.io/docs/jobs/#properties-spec)
should be used. The `system.id` should be set to
`spec.deployment/spec.name`.

attributes.name: cloudfoundry.system.instance.id
attributes.brief: A guid describing the concrete instance of the event source.
attributes.note:
CloudFoundry defines the `instance_id` in the [Loggregator v2 envelope](https://github.com/cloudfoundry/loggregator-api#v2-envelope).
It is used for logs and metrics emitted by CloudFoundry. It is
supposed to contain the vm id for CloudFoundry components.

When system components are instrumented, values from the
[Bosh spec](https://bosh.io/docs/jobs/#properties-spec)
should be used. The `system.instance.id` should be set to `spec.id`.

groups.name: cloudfoundry.system

attributes.brief: The name of the application.
attributes.note:
Application instrumentation should use the value from environment
variable `VCAP_APPLICATION.application_name`. This is the same value
as reported by `cf apps`.

attributes.brief: The guid of the application.
attributes.note:
Application instrumentation should use the value from environment
variable `VCAP_APPLICATION.application_id`. This is the same value as

attributes.brief: The guid of the CloudFoundry space the application is running in.

groups.brief: The process of the application which is monitored.

attributes.name: cloudfoundry.process.id
attributes.brief: The UID identifying the process.
attributes.note:
Application instrumentation should use the value from environment
variable `VCAP_APPLICATION.process_id`. It is supposed to be equal to
`VCAP_APPLICATION.app_id` for applications deployed to the runtime.
For system components, this could be the actual PID.

attributes.name: cloudfoundry.process.type
attributes.brief: The type of process.
attributes.note:
CloudFoundry applications can consist of multiple jobs. Usually the
main process will be of type `web`. There can be additional background
tasks or side-cars with different process types.

groups.brief: These attributes may be used for any network related operation.

attributes.name: network.local.address
attributes.brief: Local address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.local.port
attributes.brief: Local port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.peer.address
attributes.brief: Peer address of the network connection - IP address or Unix domain socket name.

attributes.name: network.peer.port
attributes.brief: Peer port number of the network connection.

attributes.name: network.protocol.name
attributes.brief: [OSI application layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_layer) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: network.protocol.version
attributes.brief: The actual version of the protocol used for network communication.
attributes.note: If protocol version is subject to negotiation (for example using [ALPN](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7301.html)), this attribute SHOULD be set to the negotiated version. If the actual protocol version is not known, this attribute SHOULD NOT be set.

attributes.name: network.transport
attributes.brief: [OSI transport layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_layer) or [inter-process communication method](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication).
attributes.note:
The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

Consider always setting the transport when setting a port number, since
a port number is ambiguous without knowing the transport. For example
different processes could be listening on TCP port 12345 and UDP port 12345.

attributes.name: network.type
attributes.brief: [OSI network layer](https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_layer) or non-OSI equivalent.
attributes.note: The value SHOULD be normalized to lowercase.

attributes.name: faas.trigger

members.brief: A response to some data source operation such as a database or filesystem read/write
To provide an answer to an inbound HTTP request
A function is set to be executed when messages are sent to a messaging system
A function is scheduled to be executed regularly
If none of the others apply

attributes.brief: Type of the trigger which caused this function invocation.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_name
attributes.brief: The name of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `faas.name` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_provider
attributes.brief: The cloud provider of the invoked function.
attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.provider` resource attribute of the invoked function.

attributes.name: faas.invoked_region
attributes.brief: The cloud region of the invoked function.

requirement_level.conditionally_required: For some cloud providers, like AWS or GCP, the region in which a function is hosted is essential to uniquely identify the function and also part of its endpoint. Since it's part of the endpoint being called, the region is always known to clients. In these cases, `faas.invoked_region` MUST be set accordingly. If the region is unknown to the client or not required for identifying the invoked function, setting `faas.invoked_region` is optional.

attributes.note: SHOULD be equal to the `cloud.region` resource attribute of the invoked function.

groups.brief: Time disk spent activated
groups.note:
The real elapsed time ("wall clock") used in the I/O path (time from operations running in parallel are not counted). Measured as:

- Linux: Field 13 from [procfs-diskstats](https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/procfs-diskstats)
- Windows: The complement of
  ["Disk\% Idle Time"](https://learn.microsoft.com/archive/blogs/askcore/windows-performance-monitor-disk-counters-explained#windows-performance-monitor-disk-counters-explained)
  performance counter: `uptime * (100 - "Disk\% Idle Time") / 100`

groups.brief: Sum of the time each operation took to complete
groups.note:
Because it is the sum of time each request took, parallel-issued requests each contribute to make the count grow. Measured as:

- Linux: Fields 7 & 11 from [procfs-diskstats](https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/procfs-diskstats)
- Windows: "Avg. Disk sec/Read" perf counter multiplied by "Disk Reads/sec" perf counter (similar for Writes)

groups.brief: Total number of processes created over uptime of the host
An estimate of how much memory is available for starting new applications, without causing swapping
groups.note:
This is an alternative to `system.memory.usage` metric with `state=free`.
Linux starting from 3.14 exports "available" memory. It takes "free" memory as a baseline, and then factors in kernel-specific values.
This is supposed to be more accurate than just "free" memory.
For reference, see the calculations [here](https://superuser.com/a/980821).
See also `MemAvailable` in [/proc/meminfo](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/proc.5.html).

groups.brief: Reports the memory used by the Linux kernel for managing caches of frequently used objects.
groups.note:
The sum over the `reclaimable` and `unreclaimable` state values in `linux.memory.slab.usage` SHOULD be equal to the total slab memory available on the system.
Note that the total slab memory is not constant and may vary over time.
See also the [Slab allocator](https://blogs.oracle.com/linux/post/understanding-linux-kernel-memory-statistics) and `Slab` in [/proc/meminfo](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/proc.5.html).

attributes.name: linux.memory.slab.state
attributes.brief: The Linux Slab memory state
